author: Scott Kraus and Ryan Kneller
title: Theater that serves beer and food coming to Trexlertown
text:
How many times have you rushed through your dinner and chugged your drink, just so you can make it to the theater in time to claim good seats for the latest Hollywood blockbuster?
A new chain of theaters coming to Trexlertown has a fix for that.
The Dallas-based Movie Tavern announced Wednesday it will open its first location in the Lehigh Valley next year in a new Jaindl Land Company retail development off Hamilton Boulevard near the Walmart Supercenter. The 46,500-square-foot theater will offer patrons food and drinks served at their seats during the movie.
"The concept is really about enjoying a wide selection of options from the menu, plus everything from a full bar, all with service right at your seat," said Danny DiGiacomo , the company's marketing director.
Future patrons could conceivably take in the next installment of the Hannibal Lecter series with some fava beans and a nice Chianti, or order a martini, shaken not stirred, to go with the latest Bond flick.

(Scott Kraus) It's part of a trend that has movie theater operators offering a range of additional amenities to make the moviegoing experience more attractive and lure customers away from the explosion of entertainment content that is available for in-home viewing on smaller screens.
Lehigh Valley residents won't have to wait until next year, though, to enjoy beer, wine and cocktails in a local movie theater.
The AMC Tilghman Square 8 on Broadway in South Whitehall Township is undergoing an extensive remodeling that includes a new bar, MacGuffins Bar & Lounge, as part of the concession offerings in the lobby. You'll have to carry the food and drink in to the theater yourself, however.
Fans of arthouse and independent films can already bring food and alcoholic drinks into the theater at Frank Banko Alehouse Cinemas at ArtsQuest Center at Steelstacks in South Bethlehem.
Other upgrades to the South Whitehall AMC theater include new plush recliners, 3D screens, sound systems and lighting in every theater, along with a new box office near the entrance. All the improvements should be complete in 3 to 4 weeks, according to project manager John Allison.
"This is a definite trend," Allison said of the bar addition. "Pretty much every theater is going this way."
MOVIE TAVERN / HANDOUT Movie Tavern, which is coming to Trexlertown in 2016, is a "combination of going out to eat in a casual dining setting and moviegoing all wrapped up into one," says Danny DiGiacomo, the company's marketing director. "The concept is really about enjoying a wide selection of options from the menu, plus everything from a full bar, all with the service right at your seat."

"The concept is really about enjoying a wide selection of options from the menu, plus everything from a full bar, all with the service right at your seat."
(MOVIE TAVERN / HANDOUT) To cope with a decade-long decline in U.S. movie theater attendance, cinema chains are adding a range of "premium offerings" that include posh seating, high-end audio and video and food and alcoholic beverage service, according to a 2014 Cinema Operator Industry Sector Review by the New York-based Redwood Capital Group.
Concessions are particularly lucrative for theaters, typically carrying a profit margin of 80 to 85 percent, according the report, compared to a 45 to 50 percent margin for admissions.
"Theaters are trying to find a way to reverse the attendance declines," said Leo Kulp, an industry analyst with RBC Capital Markets. "What they have found is these premium offerings, reclining seats, expanded menus, alcoholic beverages are bringing people back into the theaters."
The new services and upscale amenities have been particularly helpful with older patrons, who have more disposable income, Kulp said.
The growing, privately held Movie Tavern chain has two other theaters in Pennsylvania, located in Flourtown and Collegeville, both in Montgomery County. A third is scheduled to open later this year in Exton, Chester County.
"I think what's different with us is we have been doing this since 2001 and we have now 15 years of experience to consider as we grow and change our execution," DiGiacomo said. "This is what we do."
Jaindl initially proposed the development in 2004. Construction has been delayed by the recession and the plans have been revised multiple times since. In June, the developer approached Lower Macungie officials to seek construction of a traffic roundabout near the site to support the project.
In an interview Tuesday, developer David Jaindl said the roundabout won't be a part of the plan for the retail development after all because Pennsylvania Department of Transportation officials have expressed their preference for a traffic light at the site.
Movie Tavern seemed like the perfect fit, in part because its customers will come and go at different times than patrons of neighboring businesses, easing traffic concerns.
"There is nothing like them in the Valley," Jaindl said. "When they came to us, we introduced this site to them. We felt they would be good match for a project like this because of their uniqueness."
Movie Tavern will be an anchor of sorts, Jaindl said, but the development will be made up of stand-alone buildings, not in-line retail. Each site will be sold as a condominium.
Jaindl said he expects to submit formal land development plans to Lower Macungie Township officials in the next 30 days.
Jaindl said the retail center will span 32,000 square feet, in addition to the theater.
